key_risks: Environmental compliance issues, including a $42.6 million settlement with the EPA for Clean Air Act violations
Cybersecurity vulnerabilities highlighted by a 2021 incident
Supply chain disruptions and economic sensitivity to global construction and energy sectors
Intense competition from global crane manufacturers
controversies: Settlement with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Justice for Clean Air Act violations
Cybersecurity incident in 2021 that disrupted computer systems
environmental_issues: Clean Air Act violations leading to a $42.6 million settlement
Ongoing risks related to environmental regulations in North America and Europe
social_issues: Recognition as one of America’s Most Responsible Companies and a 'Best for Vets' employer, indicating strong ethical labor practices and veteran support
governance_issues: Need for enhanced compliance frameworks following the EPA settlement
Cybersecurity measures to protect against future disruptions

sources.title: Manitowoc Company Clean Air Act Settlement Summary
sources.snippet: On December 19, 2024 the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Department of Justice announced a settlement agreement with Manitowoc Company, Inc., a diesel mobile crane manufacturer, two of its subsidiaries Grove U.S. L.L.C., and Manitowoc Crane Group Germany GMBH (collectively, "Manitowoc"), for violations of the Clean Air Act's mobile sources regulations related to the sale of ...

sources.snippet: As the company moves forward post-settlement, Manitowoc is poised to enhance its compliance frameworks, ensuring that all operational aspects align with environmental regulations. sources.title: Manitowoc Crane Manufacturer Settles for $42.6 Million with DOJ & EPA ...
sources.snippet: Dec 19, 2024 - Compliance & Ethics - The Manitowoc Company Inc., a leading crane manufacturer, has found itself in hot water—and it's not the kind you'd use to make steel. In a settlement announced today, Manitowoc and two of its subsidiaries, Grove U.S. L.L.C. and Manitowoc Crane Group Germany GMBH, agreed to pay $42.6 million to resolve accusations of flouting the Clean Air Act.
